Like the king of lions, who knows the power of his body, the sharpness of his fangs and claws, and stands firmly in his cave with his four legs planted on the ground, shaking his tail and making a sound.
If there is anyone who can possess these characteristics, know that he will be able to roar the lion's roar.
The true king of lions, in the morning, emerges from his cave, stretches his body, yawns, looks around in the four directions, and emits a thundering roar for eleven reasons.
What are the eleven?

First, in order to destroy the real non-lion and pretend to be a lion; second, in order to test one's own strength; third, in order to purify the dwelling place; fourth, in order for the cubs to know the location; fifth, in order for the herd to be fearless; sixth, in order for the sleeping to awaken; seventh, in order for all careless beasts to be diligent; eighth, in order for the beasts to come and rely on it; ninth, in order to tame the great fragrant elephants; tenth, in order to teach the sons; eleventh, in order to adorn one's own retinue.

All birds and beasts hear the lion's roar, the aquatic creatures sink to the depths, the land-dwelling creatures hide in their lairs, the flying ones fall down, and the great fragrant elephants run in fear and lose their dung.
Good men!
Like that wild fox, even if it chases the lion for a hundred years, it can never make the lion's roar.
If a lion cub reaches three years old, it can roar like a lion king.
Good man!

The Tathagata's perfect enlightenment has wisdom as its fangs and claws, the four bases of supernatural powers as its feet, the six perfections as its body, the ten powers as its strength, and great compassion as its tail. He destroys the armies of Mara, displays the ten powers to the multitudes, opens up the Buddha's abode, and becomes a refuge for those of wrong views.

He comforts those who are frightened by birth and death, awakens those beings who are asleep in ignorance, causes those who practice evil to repent, and reveals the path to all beings with wrong views.

in order to cause those sentient beings to destroy their arrogance, he yawns;

Good son!

World-Honored One!

The Buddha said:
Good man!
If a bodhisattva lacks two kinds of adornments, then he will not be able to understand one kind or two kinds.

If it is said that all dharmas are neither one kind nor two kinds, this meaning is not so.

You ask:

Listen carefully, listen carefully, I will explain it to you in detail.
Good man!
Buddha-nature is called ultimate emptiness;
Ultimate emptiness is called wisdom.
What is meant by emptiness is not seeing emptiness and non-emptiness.
The wise see emptiness and non-emptiness, permanence and impermanence, suffering and happiness, self and non-self.
Emptiness refers to all birth and death;
Non-emptiness refers to great nirvana;
Up to non-self refers to birth and death, and self refers to great nirvana.
Seeing all emptiness and not seeing non-emptiness is not called the middle way;
Up to seeing all non-self and not seeing self is not called the middle way.
The middle way is called buddha-nature.
For this reason, buddha-nature is permanent, constant, and unchanging, but because it is covered by ignorance, sentient beings are unable to see it.
Sravakas and pratyekabuddhas see all emptiness and do not see non-emptiness, up to seeing all non-self and not seeing self.
For this reason, they do not attain ultimate emptiness.
Because they do not attain ultimate emptiness, they do not practice the middle way;
Because there is no middle way, they do not see the Buddha-nature.
Good man!
There are three kinds of people who do not see the middle way:

As you have asked:
'What is the meaning of the term Buddha-nature?
' Good man!

There are three kinds of paths:

Because it can attain the supreme anuttara-samyak-sambodhi.

The ultimate emptiness is not called inferior.

Because it is not attained by all ordinary beings.

Why is it so?

Furthermore, good man!ğŸ”½The fundamental state of the cycle of birth and death is of two kinds:

Between these two, there is the suffering of birth, old age, sickness, and death, which is called the middle way.
This middle way can destroy birth and death, and is therefore called the middle.
For this reason, the Dharma of the middle way is called buddha-nature.
Therefore, buddha-nature is permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Because sentient beings are unable to see it, it is impermanent, not blissful, not self, and impure. But buddha-nature is actually not impermanent, not blissful, not self, and not impure.
Good son!
It is like a poor person whose home has a treasure trove, but this person does not see it.
Because of not seeing it, it is impermanent, not blissful, not self, and not pure.
There is a good friend who says to them:
'In your house there is a treasure trove of gold. Why are you so poor, suffering, impermanent, not blissful, not self, and not pure?'
Then, using skillful means, they cause them to see it.
Because they can see it, these people immediately attain permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
Buddha-nature is also like this. Sentient beings cannot see it;
Because they cannot see it, there is no permanence, no bliss, no self, and no purity.
There are good and wise advisors, buddhas, and bodhisattvas who use skillful means to teach and instruct in various ways, enabling them to see it;
Because they can see it, sentient beings immediately attain permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
Furthermore, good man!
There are two kinds of views that sentient beings give rise to:
The first is the view of permanence, and the second is the view of annihilation.
These two views are not called the middle way. Non-permanence and non-annihilation are called the middle way.
Non-permanence and non-annihilation are the wisdom that observes and illuminates the twelve links of dependent arising. Such observing wisdom is called buddha-nature.
Although those of the two vehicles observe dependent arising, they still cannot be said to have buddha-nature.

Although buddha-nature is eternal, because beings are covered by ignorance they are unable to see it, and they are still unable to cross the river of the twelve links of dependent arising, just like rabbits and horses.

Good man!
It is like a bitter gourd called a hot illness.

Because it can serve as a cause and condition for a hot illness.
The twelve links of dependent arising are also like this.

Buddha-nature has causes and causal conditions, results and resultant states.

For this reason, the twelve links of dependent arising do not emerge or cease, are not permanent or annihilated, are not one or two, do not come or go, are neither a cause nor a result.

This is a cause but not a result.

Like the buddha-nature, which is a result but not a cause, like great nirvÄá¹‡a, which is both a cause and a result, like the dharmas produced by the twelve links of dependent arising, which are neither a cause nor a result and are called buddha-nature.

For this reason, I say in the sÅ«tras that the meaning of the twelve links of dependent arising is profound, unknowable, unseeable, and inconceivable. It is the realm of buddhas and bodhisattvas, not that of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
Why is it so profound?

Although sentient beings' karmic actions are neither permanent nor annihilated, they still receive karmic retribution. Although they cease moment by moment, nothing is lost. Although there is no doer, there is karmic action. Although there is no receiver, there is karmic retribution.
Although the receiver ceases, the result is not lost. There is no deliberation, but there is a combination.
Although all sentient beings practice together with the twelve links of dependent arising, they do not see or know it. Because they do not see or know it, there is no beginning or end.
Bodhisattvas at the tenth stage only see the end and not the beginning.
The buddhas, the world-honored ones, see the beginning and see the end.
For this reason, the buddhas clearly see the buddha-nature.
Good son!
All sentient beings are unable to see the twelve links of dependent arising, and therefore they revolve in the cycle of birth and death.
Good man!
It is like a silkworm making a cocoon, giving birth to itself and dying itself.
All sentient beings are also like this. Because they do not see buddha-nature, they create karmic bonds themselves, and revolve in birth and death like a spinning top.

Therefore, I have said in the sÅ«tras:

Good man!
Contemplating the wisdom of the twelve links of dependent arising is of four kinds:

Those of the highest wisdom see it clearly, and therefore they attain the path of unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening.
For this reason, the twelve links of dependent arising are called buddha-nature.
Buddha-nature is precisely the ultimate emptiness;
The ultimate emptiness is called the middle way;
The middle way is called the Buddha;
The Buddha is called nirvana.

The buddhas, the world-honored ones, see all dharmas as impermanent, without self, without bliss, and without purity, but they see that not all dharmas are impermanent, without self, without bliss, and without purity.

It is like the new moon, which although invisible, cannot be said to be nonexistent.

Good son!
Buddha-nature refers to the ten powers, the four kinds of fearlessness, great compassion, and the three foundations of mindfulness.
All sentient beings possess these three, but they can only be seen after destroying afflictions.
Icchantikas destroy icchantika-ness and then they can attain the ten powers, the four kinds of fearlessness, and great compassion.
For this reason, I always proclaim that all sentient beings possess Buddha-nature.
Good son!
The twelve links of dependent arising are equally possessed by all sentient beings, both internally and externally.
What are the twelve?
Past afflictions are called ignorance, and past karma is called formations;
In the present life, the initial conception in the womb is called consciousness;
The five parts of the embryo and the four faculties that are not yet complete are called name-and-form;
When one is endowed with four faculties but is not yet called contact, this is called the six sense bases;
When one does not distinguish between suffering and happiness, this is called contact;
Becoming attached to a single craving, this is called feeling;
Habitually indulging in the five desires, this is called craving;
Internally and externally grasping and seeking, this is called grasping;
For the sake of internal and external matters, one gives rise to bodily, verbal, and mental karma, this is called becoming;
Consciousness in the present world is called future birth;
Name-and-form, six sense bases, contact, and feeling in the present are called old age and death in the future world.
This is called the twelve links of dependent arising.
Good son!

Although all sentient beings have these twelve links of dependent arising, they may not yet be complete. If one dies in the kalala stage, there will be no twelve. From birth up to old age and death, one obtains the twelve.

Beings in the form realm have no three kinds of feelings, three kinds of contacts, and three kinds of craving, and no old age or sickness, and can also be said to be fully endowed with the twelve links.
Beings in the formless realm have no form up to no old age or death, and can also be said to be fully endowed with the twelve links.
Because they will definitely attain [nirvana], they are said to be equally endowed with the twelve links of dependent origination.
Good man!
The buddha-nature is also like this. All beings will definitely attain supreme, perfect enlightenment. Therefore, I say that all beings possess buddha-nature.
Good man!
There is a grass on the snow mountains called forbearance.
If cows eat it, they produce ghee.

The buddha-nature is also like this.
The snow mountains are called the Tathagata;
The grass of patience is called great nirvana;
The other grasses are the twelve divisions of the scriptures.

If sentient beings are able to listen to and inquire about the Great Nirvana Sutra, then they will see the Buddha-nature. Although it is not mentioned in the twelve divisions, one cannot say that there is no Buddha-nature.

Buddha-nature is both form and non-form, neither form nor non-form; both characteristics and non-characteristics, neither characteristics nor non-characteristics; both one and not one, neither one nor non-one; neither eternal nor annihilated, neither not eternal nor not annihilated; both existent and non-existent, neither existent nor non-existent; both exhausted and not exhausted, neither exhausted nor not exhausted; both cause and effect, neither cause nor effect; both meaning and non-meaning, neither meaning nor non-meaning; both words and non-words, neither words nor non-words.

Because it is the vajra body.

Because form and not form have no fixed characteristics.

Because of the thirty-two characteristics.

Why is it neither characteristic nor not characteristic?
Because characteristics and not characteristics are not definite.

Because all sentient beings are of the same vehicle.
Why is it not one?
Because the three vehicles are taught.
Why is it neither one nor not one?
Because of the innumerable dharmas.
Why is it impermanent?
Because it is seen to arise from conditions.
Why is it not annihilated?
Because it is free from the view of annihilation.
Why is it neither impermanent nor not annihilated?
Because it has no beginning or end.
What is existence?
Because all sentient beings possess it.
Why is it non-existence?
Because it is seen through skillful means.
What is neither existent nor nonexistent?
Because of the nature of space.
What is called exhaustion?
Because of attaining the ÅšÅ«raá¹ƒgama SamÄdhi.
What is not exhaustion?
Because it is eternal.
What is neither exhaustion nor non-exhaustion?
Because it cuts off all marks of exhaustion.
What is a cause?

What is a result?
Because it is definite.
What is neither a cause nor a result?
Because it is eternal.

Because it can completely encompass the meaning without obstruction.
What is not meaning?

Because it is ultimately empty.
What are letters?
Because it has a name.
What are not letters?
Because the name has no name.
What are neither letters nor non-letters?
Because it cuts off all letters.

Because it is permanent.

Because it does not create or receive.

Because it can serve as the seed for good dharmas.
Good sons!
If there are people who can contemplate and understand the meaning of the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra like this, know that such people will see the Buddha-nature.

The Buddha-nature is not the aggregates, realms, or sense bases, it is not originally non-existent now existent, and it is not existent that becomes non-existent again. Beings can see it from good causes and conditions.
It is like a black iron, which when put into fire becomes red, and when cooled it returns to black. This black color is neither inside nor outside, but exists due to causes and conditions.
The buddha-nature is also like this. When the fire of afflictions of all sentient beings is extinguished, they will then be able to hear and see it.

When a seed is destroyed, a sprout can then grow. The nature of this sprout is neither inside nor outside;
Up to the flowers and fruits are also like this, existing due to conditions.

This subtle sutra of the great nirvana accomplishes and possesses immeasurable merits;

At that time, Bodhisattva-mahasattva Shizihou said:

How many dharmas are possessed and accomplished by bodhisattvas to see the buddha-nature but not clearly?

What are the ten?

What is the difference between few desires and contentment?

This is for the desires of birth and death, and is called evil desires.

Not having such twenty-five kinds of craving, this is called few desires.
Not seeking future desired things, this is called few desires;
Obtaining them without attachment, this is called contentment.

There are those who have few desires but are not content, those who are content but do not have few desires, those who both have few desires and are content, and those who are neither content nor have few desires.

Why is this?
Although ordinary beings' bodies and minds are tranquil, they are unable to deeply contemplate impermanence, suffering, no-self, and impurity.
For this reason, ordinary beings are unable to tranquil their bodily, verbal, and mental actions.
Those of the icchantika class, those who commit the four grave offenses, and those who commit the five heinous crimes, such people are also not called those whose bodies and minds are tranquil.

The diligent one focuses his thoughts on the six objects, namely the Buddha, the Dharma, the Saá¹…gha, precepts, giving, and the gods. This is called right mindfulness;
One who possesses right mindfulness attains samÄdhi. This is called right concentration;
One who possesses right concentration sees all dharmas as being like empty space. This is called right wisdom;
One who possesses right wisdom distances himself from all afflictions and bonds. This is called liberation;
One who attains liberation praises liberation for the sake of sentient beings, saying that liberation is permanent, constant, and unchanging. This is called praising liberation.
Liberation is precisely the unsurpassed great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
ParinirvÄá¹‡a is the extinguishing of the fire of afflictions and bonds.
Moreover, nirvÄá¹‡a is called a house.
Why is it so?
Because it can block the evil winds and rains of afflictions.
Moreover, nirvÄá¹‡a is called a refuge.
Why is it so?
Because it can transcend all fears.
Moreover, nirvÄá¹‡a is called an island.
Why is it so?
Because the four great violent rivers cannot carry it away.
What are the four?
First, the violent river of desire; second, the violent river of existence; third, the violent river of views; fourth, the violent river of ignorance.
Therefore, nirvÄá¹‡a is called an island.
Moreover, nirvÄá¹‡a is called the ultimate refuge.
Why is it so?
Because it can attain ultimate bliss.
If a bodhisattva mahÄsattva accomplishes and is endowed with these ten dharmas, although he sees the Buddha-nature, it is not clear.
Moreover, good man!

There are four kinds of good medicine for monastics to cure these illnesses, namely:

Rag robes can cure monastics' evil desires for robes, begging for food can break the evil desires for food, sitting under trees can break the evil desires for bedding, and the tranquility of body and mind can break monastics' evil desires for existence.
Using these four medicines to cure these four illnesses is called the holy practice. Such holy practice can be called having few desires and being content.
The tranquil one has four kinds of bliss.
What are the four?
First, the bliss of leaving the household life, second, the bliss of tranquility, third, the bliss of complete cessation, and fourth, the ultimate bliss.
Attaining these four pleasures is called tranquility;
Being endowed with four kinds of diligence is called diligence;ğŸ”½Being endowed with the four establishments of mindfulness is called right mindfulness;

Seeing the four noble truths is called right wisdom;
Permanently severing all afflictive bonds is called liberation;
Reproaching and speaking of the faults of all afflictions is called praising liberation.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who abide in and are endowed with these ten dharmas, although they see the Buddha-nature, it is not clear.
Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who have heard this sÅ«tra and are close to and cultivate it, distancing themselves from all worldly affairs, this is called having few desires.
Having gone forth, they do not give rise to regret, this is called contentment.
Having been content, they are close to secluded places and distance themselves from busyness and noise, this is called tranquility.
Those who are not content do not enjoy solitude.
Those who are content always enjoy emptiness and tranquility. In a place of emptiness and tranquility, they always think like this:
'All in the world say that I have attained the fruits of the path of Å›ramaá¹‡as, but I have not yet been able to do so. How can I deceive others?
' Having thought this, they diligently cultivate the fruits of the path of Å›ramaá¹‡as. This is called vigor.

Those with right view and knowledge are able to attain liberation from the bonds of afflictions. This is called liberation.
Bodhisattvas in the ten abodes praise nirvÄá¹‡a for the sake of sentient beings. This is called praising liberation.

As for having few desires, if a bhiká¹£u dwells in an empty and quiet place, sitting upright without lying down, or dwells under a tree, in a charnel ground, or in the open, sitting on the grass wherever it may be, begging for food and eating what he obtains, content with whatever he gets, eating only one meal a day, not eating after the proper time, only keeping three robes, rag robes, and woolen robes, this is called having few desires.

Good man!
